title: Huawei Accuses the U.S. of Cyberattacks and Staff Threats
text:
HONG KONG—China’s Huawei Technologies Co. accused the U.S. of “using every tool at its disposal” to disrupt its business, including launching cyberattacks on its networks and instructing law enforcement to “menace” its employees.

The telecommunications giant also said law enforcement in the U.S. have searched, detained and arrested Huawei employees and its business partners, and have sent FBI agents to the homes of its workers to pressure them to collect information on behalf of the U.S.

Huawei’s accusations describe a broad campaign by U.S. officials to disrupt and stymie the company’s business activities globally. Such tactics, Huawei said, also include using visa denials, detaining shipments and resurfacing settled civil cases as criminal charges. In unspecified instances, it said, the U.S. even had officials “pretending to be Huawei employees” to drum up charges against the company.

Huawei detailed the allegations against the U.S. in a press release issued on Tuesday, in which it also denied stealing smartphone-camera technology from Portuguese multimedia producer Rui Oliveira and accused him of “taking advantage of the current geopolitical situation.”

China is locked in a trade dispute with Washington and struggling to deal with protests in Hong Kong. China’s Foreign Ministry earlier this year characterized U.S. actions on Huawei as “economic bullying” and an attempt to block China’s rise.

Huawei’s press release didn’t provide specific evidence to back up the allegations. However, a person familiar with the matter said at least three employees from Huawei’s U.S. office have been contacted by U.S. law enforcement agencies since the beginning of 2019.

Related Video The U.S. blacklisting of Huawei is cutting off American businesses from a big client. WSJ’s Dan Strumpf looks at the American technology that has powered the Chinese company’s smartphones. Photo composite: Sharon Shi

The Justice Department said it doesn’t comment on specific investigations but said the investigative techniques it uses are lawful. The department has said China is implicated in more than 80% of the economic espionage claims that it has charged or prosecuted. A representative for the FBI declined to comment.

When investigating allegations of criminal misconduct at a company, it is common for FBI agents to visit current or former employees of the company at their homes, in an effort to persuade them to cooperate in their investigation and to help obtain evidence.

The Wall Street Journal last week reported that U.S. prosecutors were investigating several new alleged instances of intellectual-property theft by Huawei, including allegations that it stole smartphone-camera technology from Mr. Oliveira. Huawei received a subpoena requesting documents about the instances of alleged theft, the Journal reported.

Mr. Oliveira plans to respond to Huawei in court next week, and declined to provide further comment, his attorney, Jeffrey Wadsworth, said in an email.

In addition to denying Mr. Oliveira’s claims, Huawei leveled a number of new accusations against the U.S. Among them, it said the U.S. was “instructing law enforcement to threaten, menace, coerce, entice and incite both current and former Huawei employees to turn against the company and work for them.”

The allegations are the latest exchange in a fight between the U.S. and Huawei—the world’s largest maker of telecommunications equipment and the No. 2 smartphone maker—that has been running for more than a year.

Huawei has been fighting a series of escalating actions by the U.S., including two criminal indictments and a campaign to pressure U.S. allies against using Huawei gear in their 5G network rollouts.

In an appearance with Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar in Dublin Tuesday, Vice President Mike Pence repeated the Trump administration’s contention that Huawei gear poses a security threat.

“It is well known that Chinese law requires Chinese telecom companies to provide Beijing’s vast security apparatus with access to any data that touches their network,” Mr. Pence said.

The stakes are high for Huawei and other telecom-equipment vendors as countries around the world prepare to deploy 5G, the next generation of superfast networks expected to bring connectivity to an array of new devices—but that security experts and government officials say could entail new vulnerabilities.

Huawei’s contention that the U.S. is resurfacing resolved civil cases is an apparent reference to an indictment issued by U.S. prosecutors in January. That indictment accused Huawei of stealing smartphone-testing technology from its former partner T-Mobile US Inc. The indictment arose out of a civil suit filed by T-Mobile that was resolved in 2017, with a jury finding Huawei liable for breach of contract and ordering it to pay $4.8 million to its former partner. The dispute with Mr. Oliveira is a continuing civil case.

The allegations by Huawei come as the company has taken a more aggressive posture in response to U.S. actions in the past year. In March, the company filed a lawsuit in Texas federal court challenging portions of a law blocking its gear from being used by the government or contractors. Its once-reclusive founder and former Chinese army officer, Ren Zhengfei, has given a series of interviews hitting back at the U.S.

Huawei’s allegations come after wide-ranging inquiries on the company’s business practices by the FBI and prosecutors from the Eastern District of New York.

The fresh lines of investigation by U.S. officials cover issues raised over two decades by people and companies that have accused Huawei of stealing their intellectual property. They overlap with a Journal story in May that detailed allegations by accusers ranging from longtime tech peers, including Cisco Technology Inc. and T-Mobile US Inc., to smaller businessmen including Mr. Oliveira and a musician in Seattle.

On Tuesday, Huawei also accused the U.S. of launching investigations based on “false media reports that target the company.” Huawei singled out Mr. Oliveira, saying he was providing a “false narrative” to the media to hurt Huawei and extort from it. Mr. Oliveira told the Journal earlier this year that he met Huawei executives in May 2014 due to their interest in his two U.S. patents for a camera attachment to smartphones. He accused Huawei of stealing his intellectual property from these patents and threatened a lawsuit against Huawei.

The company sued Mr. Oliveira in March, asking a Texas federal court to issue a noninfringement ruling. The litigation remains unresolved. Huawei said it wasn’t interested in Mr. Oliveira’s design after their meeting and didn’t use Mr. Oliveira’s design, and that its product was different from Mr. Oliveira’s in key aspects. Mr. Oliveira referred the accusations to an attorney.

Huawei on Tuesday broadly denied the allegation that its record has been dotted with accusations of dubious methods.

“No company becomes a global leader in their field through theft,” it said.

—Aruna Viswanatha and Catherine Lucey contributed to this article.
